message_1:
A math student is studying mirror symmetry and its applications. Here's a problem:

In algebraic geometry, mirror symmetry predicts that the number of rational curves of degree $d$ on one side of a mirror pair of Calabi-Yau 3-folds is the same as the number of holomorphic discs of area $d$ on the other side of the mirror.

Let's consider a mirror pair of Calabi-Yau 3-folds. If the number of rational curves of degree 3 on the first side of the mirror is 25, how many holomorphic discs of area 3 are predicted to lie on the mirror partner?
message_2: Since mirror symmetry predicts that the number of rational curves of degree $d$ on one side of a mirror pair of Calabi-Yau 3-folds is the same as the number of holomorphic discs of area $d$ on the other side of the mirror, we can conclude that if there are 25 rational curves of degree 3 on the first side of the mirror, there will also be 25 holomorphic discs of area 3 on the mirror partner.
